Starting with Firefox 8, the preference browser.sessionstore.max_concurrent_tabs was removed (see Bug 648683) and was replaced with a "switch" (browser.sessionstore.restore_on_demand) that is accessible from the Preferences window and only accepts 2 values: true (tabs are loaded only when selected) or false (all tabs are loaded, 3 at a time)
The value "3 at a time" is now hard-coded and cannot be customized as was previously possible with the preference max_concurrent_tabs.
My question is: why hard-coded? why 3? Was there any performance analysis showing that loading 3 tabs at a time finished loading all tabs quicker than loading, say, 5 tabs at a time or 10 tabs at a time?
I'm a heavy tabs user (> 50 tabs) and I had my max_concurrent_tabs preference customized to 8 tabs at a time. When I updated to firefox 8, that value was obviously reset to 3 tabs at a time. I can now see a noticeable delay in the total time it takes to load all my tabs after a restart.
Would it be possible to bring back the preference max_concurrent_tabs? Or, at least, to change the hard-coded value of "3 tabs at a time" to some higher value? (5? 6? 8 tabs at a time?)
I think many heavy users like me would appreciate such a change. And, after all, this preference is precisely geared towards heavy users. People who only open a couple of tabs certainly don't need these preferences.
